title: How to Make Friendship Fairy Bread

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 F or 180 C. Melt the butter in a saucepan.
steps.description: When the butter is melted, set it aside to cool. It is important that you cool the butter before working with it because you do not want the sugar to melt too fast - you want it crystallized on the top of each biscuit.

steps.headline: Combine the white sugar, brown sugar and cinnamon in a bowl.
steps.description: Flatten or roll out the buttermilk biscuits, making sure to lay them on a flat surface. This step is optional, but if you want to take this recipe to the next level, do not skip this step! If you do choose to skip this step, bear in mind you will still have to make the sugar mixture.

steps.headline: Cut a shallow hole in the center of each biscuit with a small, sharp knife.
steps.description: Fill the biscuit holes with a small amount of the sugar mixture, then cover the holes with the biscuit center that was cut out.

steps.headline: Dust or sprinkle a little of the sugar mixture onto the tops of every biscuit.
steps.description: Using a muffin tray lined with cupcake wrappers, place about one or two biscuits (or three or four depending on the size) inside every wrapper.

steps.headline: Drizzle a little of the cooled melted butter onto every biscuit in the individual wrappers, making sure "not to overcoat" each biscuit.
steps.description: Sprinkle on the remaining sugar mixture if there is any left. In the case where you have run out of the sugar mixture, sprinkle on some cinnamon instead.

steps.headline: Bake the friendship fairy bread in the oven for about 5-8 minutes or until the sugar has melted onto the biscuits.
steps.description: Take the fairy bread cups and leave them on a wire rack to cool. Do not leave them inside the muffin tray - it will be harder to cool.

steps.headline: Combine powdered sugar, lemon juice and water in a bowl.
steps.description: If desired, you can add a few drops of food coloring. The consistency of the icing should be runny, but not too runny where it is like water. It should be opaque as well. You can omit the lemon juice and use other extracts as well. If you want to keep your icing plain, it tastes great that way too. You can also substitute water for milk! Use less milk though, because it is richer. However, it is entirely up to you.

steps.headline: Drizzle the icing onto the fairy bread cups.
steps.description: Lastly, sprinkle some 100s and 1000s to complete the fairy bread cups. You can wait until the icing has set to serve them, or you can eat them immediately.

steps.headline: Cut off the crusts of your bread.
steps.description: You could keep the bread as it is, in squares, but for a more impressive looking snack, slice the bread into triangles. Set aside.

steps.headline: Place a serving plate in front of you.
steps.description: To the side, have your butter, jam and 100s and 1000s ready as well. Don't forget to include two knives - one for the butter and one for the jam.

steps.headline: Separate the triangles of bread into two stacks - one for butter and one for jam.
steps.description: Take one slice of bread, and spread either butter or jam on the top. Then, spread a bit of jam onto the plate; it will help to stick the first slice of bread. 'Glue' your first triangle of bread onto the spot where you smeared on the jam. To make your snack more impressive (as mentioned earlier), smear the jam in two areas. This way, you will have two triangular stacks that when pressed together, form a square.

steps.headline: Repeat the spreading and 'sticking' process.
steps.description: Repeat with every slice of bread - spread some jam onto a slice and stick it on. Spread some butter on a slice and stick it on. Continue this, remembering not to put any 100s and 1000s just yet, until there is one last piece of bread for each stack (you will have two pieces of bread).

steps.headline: Take the last pieces of bread, and spread either butter or jam - whatever comes next in the order of which you placed the other slices of bread.
steps.description: Stick them on, and sprinkle on the 100s and 1000s. Now, your two triangular fairy bread stacks should form a square. Go ahead and press them together to form a square, if you haven't already.

steps.headline: Spread jam all over the "sides" of the square fairy bread stack.
steps.description: Do not coat thickly - only a small amount will do. Pour a handful of 100s and 1000s into your hand and press onto the sides of the stack, coating it with a 100s and 1000s shell.

steps.headline: Keep on creating the 100s and 1000s 'shell' until all the sides have been covered.
steps.description: Then, stand back and enjoy your marvelous creation!

text: Friendship Fairy Bread Cups Preheat the oven to 350 F or 180 C. Melt the butter in a saucepan. When the butter is melted, set it aside to cool. It is important that you cool the butter before working with it because you do not want the sugar to melt too fast - you want it crystallized on the top of each biscuit. Combine the white sugar, brown sugar and cinnamon in a bowl. Flatten or roll out the buttermilk biscuits, making sure to lay them on a flat surface. This step is optional, but if you want to take this recipe to the next level, do not skip this step! If you do choose to skip this step, bear in mind you will still have to make the sugar mixture. Cut a shallow hole in the center of each biscuit with a small, sharp knife. Fill the biscuit holes with a small amount of the sugar mixture, then cover the holes with the biscuit center that was cut out. Dust or sprinkle a little of the sugar mixture onto the tops of every biscuit. Using a muffin tray lined with cupcake wrappers, place about one or two biscuits (or three or four depending on the size) inside every wrapper. Drizzle a little of the cooled melted butter onto every biscuit in the individual wrappers, making sure "not to overcoat" each biscuit. Sprinkle on the remaining sugar mixture if there is any left. In the case where you have run out of the sugar mixture, sprinkle on some cinnamon instead. Bake the friendship fairy bread in the oven for about 5-8 minutes or until the sugar has melted onto the biscuits. Take the fairy bread cups and leave them on a wire rack to cool. Do not leave them inside the muffin tray - it will be harder to cool. Combine powdered sugar, lemon juice and water in a bowl. If desired, you can add a few drops of food coloring. The consistency of the icing should be runny, but not too runny where it is like water. It should be opaque as well. You can omit the lemon juice and use other extracts as well. If you want to keep your icing plain, it tastes great that way too. You can also substitute water for milk! Use less milk though, because it is richer. However, it is entirely up to you. Drizzle the icing onto the fairy bread cups. Lastly, sprinkle some 100s and 1000s to complete the fairy bread cups. You can wait until the icing has set to serve them, or you can eat them immediately. Friendship Fairy Bread Stack Cut off the crusts of your bread. You could keep the bread as it is, in squares, but for a more impressive looking snack, slice the bread into triangles. Set aside. Place a serving plate in front of you. To the side, have your butter, jam and 100s and 1000s ready as well. Don't forget to include two knives - one for the butter and one for the jam. Separate the triangles of bread into two stacks - one for butter and one for jam. Take one slice of bread, and spread either butter or jam on the top. Then, spread a bit of jam onto the plate; it will help to stick the first slice of bread. 'Glue' your first triangle of bread onto the spot where you smeared on the jam. To make your snack more impressive (as mentioned earlier), smear the jam in two areas. This way, you will have two triangular stacks that when pressed together, form a square. Repeat the spreading and 'sticking' process. Repeat with every slice of bread - spread some jam onto a slice and stick it on. Spread some butter on a slice and stick it on. Continue this, remembering not to put any 100s and 1000s just yet, until there is one last piece of bread for each stack (you will have two pieces of bread). Take the last pieces of bread, and spread either butter or jam - whatever comes next in the order of which you placed the other slices of bread. Stick them on, and sprinkle on the 100s and 1000s. Now, your two triangular fairy bread stacks should form a square. Go ahead and press them together to form a square, if you haven't already. Spread jam all over the "sides" of the square fairy bread stack. Do not coat thickly - only a small amount will do. Pour a handful of 100s and 1000s into your hand and press onto the sides of the stack, coating it with a 100s and 1000s shell. Keep on creating the 100s and 1000s 'shell' until all the sides have been covered. Then, stand back and enjoy your marvelous creation! Enjoy!  Finished.
